messages.content: What is OpenVoice?
OpenVoice is a state-of-the-art, source-available voice cloning technology targeted at developers and researchers, not end users.
Does OpenVoice clone the accent and emotion of the reference voice?
No, OpenVoice only clones the tone color of the reference speaker. The accent and emotion are controlled by the base speaker TTS model, not cloned by the tone color converter.
How can users change the accent or emotion of the output in OpenVoice?

Users need to have a base speaker model with the desired accent to change the accent or emotion of the output. OpenVoice provides flexibility for users to integrate their own base speaker model into the framework.
What should users check if the generated speech has bad audio quality?

Users should check if the reference audio is clean without background noise, not too short, contains speech from only one person, does not have long blank sections, and if they have deleted the 'processed' folder if reusing the same name for the reference audio.
Does OpenVoice support languages other than English?

Yes, OpenVoice supports any language as long as there is a base speaker in that language. The tone color converter training is done by the OpenVoice team, and base speaker TTS models can be trained using existing open-source repositories or by using the OpenAI TTS model as the base speaker.
What should users do if they encounter an error related to Silero during installation?

If the download fails due to inability to access GitHub, users should manually download the zip from 'https://github.com/snakers4/silero-vad/zipball/master' and unzip it to '/home/user/.cache/torch/hub/snakers4_silero-vad_master'.
Is OpenVoice a ready-to-use perfect voice cloning product?

No, OpenVoice is not a ready-to-use perfect voice cloning product. It is a versatile instant voice cloning technical approach that accelerates the open research community's progress on instant voice cloning.
What is ComfyUI OpenVoice?
ComfyUI OpenVoice is an unofficial support for OpenVoice in ComfyUI, which allows users to perform text-to-speech (TTS) and speech-to-speech (STS) tasks using reference voices.
When was OpenVoice V2 support added to ComfyUI OpenVoice?
OpenVoice V2 support was added to ComfyUI OpenVoice on May 14, 2024.
When were ComfyUI nodes and workflow examples added to ComfyUI OpenVoice?
ComfyUI nodes and workflow examples were added to ComfyUI OpenVoice on April 12, 2024.
Which language only supports the 'default' style in ComfyUI OpenVoice?
In ComfyUI OpenVoice, the Chinese language only supports the 'default' style.
What are the basic usages shown in the provided workflow example?
The provided workflow example demonstrates the basic usages of text-to-speech (TTS) and speech-to-speech (STS) using reference voices in ComfyUI OpenVoice.
What is required to install ComfyUI OpenVoice from ComfyUI Manager?
To install ComfyUI OpenVoice from ComfyUI Manager, search for 'openvoice' and ensure that 'ffmpeg' is installed.
What extra installation steps are needed for OpenVoice V2 support?
To enable OpenVoice V2 support, users need to install mecab, libmecab-dev, and download the MeloTTS GitHub repository and unidic.
Are the models for ComfyUI OpenVoice downloaded automatically?
Yes, all the models for ComfyUI OpenVoice are downloaded automatically, so there is no need to worry about manual downloads.
What are the options available for quick use of OpenVoice?

Quick use of OpenVoice provides options to clone voices in British English, American English, Indian English, Australian English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean. These options can be accessed by clicking on the respective links provided.
How can a user install OpenVoice on a Windows system?
A specific guide for installing OpenVoice on a Windows system is not found in the provided document. However, there is a guide available for an installation process on a Docker container.
What are the main features of OpenVoice V2?
OpenVoice V2 natively supports English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean. It also improves upon the voice cloning capabilities, allowing for the use of any input speech in any language.
For which languages can OpenVoice V2 use input speech audio?
OpenVoice V2 can use input speech audio in English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean.
How can a user install OpenVoice on a Docker container?
A guide on installing OpenVoice on a Docker container is available. However, the specific instructions are not included in the provided document excerpt.
What is the purpose of the flexvoice module?
The flexvoice module allows for flexible voice style control, which is a main feature of OpenVoice V2.
What is the 'melo++' model used for in OpenVoice V2?
The 'melo++' model is used in the model selection section of OpenVoice V2 to select the most appropriate model for the input speech audio.
Can OpenVoice be used cross-lingually?
Yes, OpenVoice can perform cross-lingual voice cloning. This is demonstrated in the `demo_part2.ipynb` notebook in OpenVoice V1.
What platforms doesn't OpenVoice officially support?
OpenVoice officially supports Linux, and the specific instructions for installation on other platforms are provided under the 'Install on Other Platforms' section.
What is the difference between OpenVoice V1 and V2?
OpenVoice V2 includes advancements over V1, such as supporting additional languages (English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean) and using the native capabilities of MeloTTS.
In the gradio demo, why does OpenVoice V1 recommend looking into `demo_part1.ipynb`, `demo_part2.ipynb`, and the FAQ if having issues?

The gradio demo might not cover all possible issues that users could encounter. Therefore, for users having issues with the demo, documentation resources like `demo_part1.ipynb`, `demo_part2.ipynb`, and the QnA are recommended for additional information and troubleshooting.
What operating system does OpenVoice best run on?
OpenVoice appears to run most efficiently on Linux, specifically as outlined in the 'Linux Install' section.
How can third-party contributions help maintain the quality of OpenVoice?

Third-party contributions, such as installation guides for other platforms, can help ensure that the community remains involved and contributes to the overall quality and reach of OpenVoice. Guidelines are provided in the 'Install on Other Platforms' section for contributors to submit their own guides once they have a better installation method for OpenVoice.
What tools does OpenVoice use for flexible style control?
OpenVoice utilizes the stable diffusion model within the ComfyUI GUI to enable flexible style control over the cloned voice.
How can researchers and developers be involved with OpenVoice?

Researchers and developers can contribute to OpenVoice by submitting better installation guides for other platforms that they believe could benefit the community. These guides will be acknowledged and listed under the respective platform's section in the official documentation.
Which languages have been trained by OpenVoice?
As per the document, OpenVoice V1 has been trained on materials from the Old Datasets seen in the MSML training set. OpenVoice V2 supports English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean.
What language classes do OpenVoice handle?
The document mentions that OpenVoice can handle British English, American English, Indian English, Australian English, Spanish, French, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean.
